paragraph.paragraph: The Advanced Property Page contains all of the more advanced options used to modifiy how the compiler compiles your project.
paragraph.heading: 2Code Generation
3Optimize Code
paragraph.paragraph: When set to true the compiler will finalize your projects code. The overall process reduces the size and speeds up execution of the compiled project. It is recommeded that this option is set to true for release configurations and set to false for all debugging configurations.
paragraph.heading: 3.NET Naming Convention
paragraph.paragraph: When set to True the compiler will convert and emit namespace, class and features names in to Pascal case, mirroring that of the Microsoft .NET Foundation Classes. When false all namespace, class and feature names will remain as is.
paragraph.heading: 3Cluster Namespace
paragraph.paragraph: The Cluster Namespace property defines the way the compiler handles the generation of namespaces for your project's clusters.

list.item: No Namespace: All classes are placed in the root namespace

Cluster Name: Only those clusters specified in the Cluster Property Page have namespaces emitted for their containing classes. If a cluster has the All or Library set then all classes located in subdirectories of that cluster will be under the specified cluster's namespace.
Full Cluster Name: Similar to Cluster Name. However, if a cluster has the All or Library set then all classes located in subdirectories of that cluster will extend thespecified cluster's namespace.

paragraph.heading: 3Target CLR Version
paragraph.paragraph: If both version 1.0 and 1.1 of the .NET framework are installed then this option becomes available for use. Setting to v1.0.3705 willforce the compiler totarget your project for version 1.0 of the CLR. Setting to v1.1.4322 will force the compiler to target your project for version 1.1 of the CLR. The Automatic option will automatically select the a version of the CLR depending upong what version of Visual Studio .NET your project is loaded in. Visual Studio .NET 2002 will target version 1.0 and Visual Studio .NET 2003 will target version 1.1 of the CLR.

NB. All referenced assemblies that reside in %SystemRoot%\Microsoft.NET\Framework\<any version> folder will be automatically changed to the correctversion corresponding to the targetted version of the CLR.
paragraph.warning: Warning: If you are using a precompiled library, ensure that it was compiled targetting the same version of the CLR.
paragraph.heading: 3Support CLR Version
paragraph.paragraph: Supportting a version of the CLR creates an application configuration file for your project. Itcontains all ofthe required information for demoting or premoting it's referenced assemblies, at runtime, to an alternative version. Setting to v1.0.3705 will ensure that the CLR will only load version 1.0of the referenced Microsoft .NET Base Class Libraries. Setting to v1.1.4322 will ensure that the CLR will only load version 1.1of the referenced Microsoft .NET Base Class Libraries. Setting to Both will support both version of the CLR. The Automatic option will automatically select the a version of the CLR depending upong what version of Visual Studio .NET your project is loaded in. Visual Studio .NET 2002 will target version 1.0 and Visual Studio .NET 2003 will target version 1.1 of the CLR.
paragraph.heading: 2Compiler Warnings
3Show Compiler Warnings
paragraph.paragraph: When set to True all compiler warnings the compiler raises are shown in the Build Output pane. When False all compiler related warnings such as obsolete call, syntax warnings etc. are omitted from the output.
paragraph.heading: 2COM Interop
3Register for COM Interop
paragraph.paragraph: On a successful compilation you project will be registered for COM interopability, when set to True, post a successful compilation.
paragraph.note: Note: The Microsoft .NET Framework SDK must be installed for use with this option.
